misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay linked after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because `names` and `scores` represent the same students conceptually, sorting the `scores` array will keep the correct name-score pairing (i.e., the “link” between arrays is preserved automatically).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent data structures. `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` reorders only the elements inside `studentScoresArray`. It does not (and cannot) automatically apply the same swaps to `studentNamesArray`. To keep parallel arrays aligned, you must swap both arrays together during sorting, or sort indices/objects that bundle name+score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed top student name may not correspond to the highest score (e.g., sample input would output `Charlie (92)` instead of `Bob (92)`).

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Desynchronization on Single-Array Sort
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when you sort one of two parallel arrays independently using Arrays.sort(), the relationship between the corresponding elements in both arrays is somehow magically preserved. The student thinks: 'I have names and scores in parallel arrays. If I sort just the scores array, the names array will stay synchronized with it because they represent the same students conceptually.'
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fundamentally misunderstands how Arrays.sort() works. Arrays.sort() only rearranges elements within the single array it operates on. It has no knowledge of other arrays and performs no cross-array synchronization. When you call Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray), only the scores are reordered; the names array remains completely unchanged. The parallel relationship is broken because the student did not swap corresponding elements in both arrays during the sorting process. To maintain parallel arrays, you must swap elements in BOTH arrays together whenever you swap elements during sorting, or use a different approach (like sorting indices, using a custom Comparator with a wrapper class, etc.).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print the highest score correctly, but will pair it with the wrong student name (whatever name happened to be at the last position in the original input, not the name of the student who actually achieved that score).

evidence.code_snippet:
String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];
int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[highestScoreIndex];

// Now we sort the scores array so that the highest score ends up at the end
// I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java automatically maintains the relationship between two parallel arrays such that an operation like sorting on one array will automatically reorder the elements in the second array to preserve the original index-based associations.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The 'parallel' relationship is purely a semantic convention used by the programmer and is not enforced or recognized by the Java Virtual Machine. Functions like Arrays.sort() only manipulate the specific array passed as an argument and have no knowledge of other data structures that the programmer considers linked.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay linked when one array is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names[] and scores[] arrays "represent the same students", sorting scores[] will also keep the corresponding name at the same index in names[], so the last name will automatically match the highest score after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, two separate arrays have no automatic relationship. Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray) only rearranges the integers inside studentScoresArray; it does not (and cannot) rearrange studentNamesArray to match. After sorting, the indices in scores[] no longer correspond to the same student as the indices in names[]. To sort parallel arrays by score, you must swap elements in *both* arrays together during sorting (or combine the data into objects and sort those).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints an incorrect student name for the highest score whenever the top score was not originally at the last index (e.g., sample input would print "Charlie (92)" instead of "Bob (92)").

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
// Since the arrays are conceptually linked, the last name should match the last score

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a pair of parallel arrays will automatically maintain the correspondence between them. The student thinks that since the names and scores 'represent the same students,' sorting the scores array will keep the link intact, such that the name at the highest score index will still correspond to that score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that `Arrays.sort()` only sorts the specified array in place. It does not modify or reorder any other array. When you sort `studentScoresArray`, the `studentNamesArray` remains completely unchanged. Parallel arrays require explicit manual synchronization: when one array is modified (e.g., sorted), the other must be modified in lockstep using the same swaps/operations, or a different data structure must be used.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];
int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[highestScoreIndex];
// I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are intended to be 'parallel' (where indices represent the same entity), performing a sorting operation on one array will automatically reorder the other array to maintain the association between values.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects with no inherent connection. The 'parallel' nature of two arrays is purely a convention established by the programmer's logic; the JVM does not track or maintain relationships between distinct array objects. Sorting one array via Arrays.sort() does not trigger a corresponding reordering in any other array.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
